STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 13, 2021
Melanie Williams
Ennis Center For Children - Detroit
20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
RE: License #: CB820201107
Ennis Center for Children - Detroit
20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
Dear Ms. Williams:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on June 14,
2021 - July 12, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact my area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Alicia Wiggins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 917-1048
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
In one out of six certification records reviewed, one foster home did not complete first
aid training.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(i) A copy of all special evaluations completed during the last
2 years.
In one out of three borrowed home records, which had special evaluations, the
October 29, 2020 special evaluation was not in the record when it was reviewed.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
4

(2)(b) In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the updated service
plans (USPs) were not completed timely.
 For one record, the USP was due on May 25, 2020, and it was completed on
May 27, 2020.
 For one record, the USP was due on April 22, 2021, and it was completed on
April 23, 2021.
(3) In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which required a modified
plan, the modified plan was not completed timely. The agency received case
responsibility on July 9, 2020. The modified plan was completed on September 1,
2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (2)(b) and (3) — 2019 Interim Inspection,
CAP approved August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (2)(b) and (3) — 2020 Renewal
Inspection, CAP approved May 21, 2020.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
In two out of three adoption family records reviewed, the adoption evaluation was
not completed within 90 days of the family signing an adoption application.
 For one record, the adoption application was signed on February 11, 2020,
and the adoption evaluation was completed on April 22, 2021.
 For one record, the adoption application was signed on August 29, 2019, and
the adoption evaluation was completed on October 22, 2020.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
In one out of three adoption family records reviewed, there was no verification that
the applicants were provided with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
5

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Relative Engagement and Placement.
FOM 722-03B
The DHS-3130A, Relative Placement Home Study, is a
comprehensive home assessment that considers multiple
domains in a prospective caregiver's life. The DHS-3130A
allows caseworkers to identify strengths and barriers that may
impact a child's placement. The DHS-3130A must be completed
within the timeframes described below:
 For emergency placements, within 30 calendar days of
the child’s placement in the relative home.
 For planned placement changes, prior to placement in
the relative home, but within 30 calendar days of the
written request.
 For requests received when the child is placed with a
relative, within 90 calendar days of the written request;
see Multiple Relatives Interested in Placement in this
item.
Note: This extended timeframe is only to be used when there is
not an immediate need for a placement change, e.g., when the
child is in a stable placement with another relative.
The DHS-3130A including all clearances must be completed
and approved annually (within 365 days of the previous DHS-
3130A completion date) for unlicensed caregivers. An approved
DHS-3130A is valid for one year.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which required a relative home
study, the home study was not completed timely.
 For one record, the child was placed in the relative home on March 1, 2021,
and the relative home study was completed on June 14, 2021.
 For one record, the annual relative home study was not completed in 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
6

 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Documentation
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting (FTM) Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
In two out eight foster children’s records reviewed, a FTM was not completed timely.
 For one record, a FTM for case service plan development for the USP ending
on May 25, 2020, was not completed within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
 For one record, a FTM for case service plan development for the USP ending
on March 24, 2021, was not completed within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Efforts to Identify and Locate Absent/Putative Parent:
FOM 722-06G Location Efforts.
Location efforts must be documented in all case service plans
and in the social work contacts section of the case service plan.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which there was an absent
parent, the efforts to locate the parent was not documented in all of the case service
plans. There was documented efforts to locate the absent parent in the report ending
on November 21, 2020, however, the reports ending on March 24, 2021, and June
22, 2021, did not include efforts.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. This includes the following:
7

• Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
 Foster care worker.
 Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
 Sibling/child face-to face contacts.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all contacts were not entered
in MiSACWIS within five business days of the contact.
 For one record, the sibling visit for September 2020 was completed on
September 5, 2020, and it was entered in MiSACWIS on July 9, 2021.
 For one record, sibling visits were completed on December 9, 2020, January
27, 2021, February 5, 2021, March 12, 2021, and April 16, 2021, and they
were entered in MiSACWIS on July 9, 2021.
 For one record, a face-to-face with a child was completed on June 3, 2021,
and it was entered in MiSACWIS on July 12, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Child in Out-of-Home Placement.
FOM 722-06H
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Move
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with the child for the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face
contact with the child must take place within five business days
from the date the case is assigned to the caseworker or within
five business days of the date of the placement move. At least
one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location. Each contact must include a private
meeting between the child and the caseworker; see Private
Meeting in this item.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child each calendar month. At least one contact each
calendar month must take place at the child’s placement
location. Each contact must include a private meeting between
the child and the caseworker.
8

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which the child had a
change of placement, there was only one face-to-face contact with the child for the
first month after the change of placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact with
the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s residence. One of the face-to-face contacts must be
used to discuss the following:
• Petition and court orders.
• Case service plan.
• Family Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
• Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
• Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement.
• Scheduling and expectations of parenting time.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
9

In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, for the subsequent months, the
caseworker did not have face-to-face contact with each parent/guardian at least
once each calendar month.
 For one record, there were no face-to-face visits or contact with the parents in
May 2020, with the mother in July 2020, and with the mother in March 2021.
 For one record, there were no face-to-face visits or contact with the mother in
July 2020 and with the mother in August 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED — 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Contact with Child’s Caregivers.
FOM 722-06H
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there is more than
one caregiver, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the relative caregiver was not
visited in the relative caregiver’s home in May 2021.
DHHS Policy Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact:
FOM 722-06I Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time. For the purposes of visitation only, siblings
include children related through birth, adoption, or marriage and
include siblings as defined by the American Indian or Alaskan
Native child's tribal code or custom. A sibling relationship
continues after termination of parental rights or when a marriage
ends by death or divorce.
10

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which siblings are not
placed together, all of the monthly sibling visits were not completed. Sibling visits
did not occur in January 2021, February 2021, March 2021, and May 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722-08C Agreement. (Signatures)
For both ISP and USP, the PATP must be signed by the worker,
supervisor, parent(s), foster parents/caregivers, and children 14
years and older.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the required signatures were
not obtained for the PATP.
 For one record, the parent and caregiver did not sign the PATP for report
period ending on May 19, 2020. The parent did not sign the PATP for report
period ending on May 07, 2021.
 For one record, the parent did not sign the PATP for report periods ending on
January 24, 2021, and April 24, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Foster Care Juvenile/Juvenile Action Plan Summary.
FOM 722-08E
Prior to a planned placement change, or within three business
days of an emergency placement change, the caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS.
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure, the caseworker must complete the DHS-
69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary and upload to
MiSACWIS.
11

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which had a placement
change, the DHS-69 form was not completed within three business days of the
placement change. The child’s placement changed on March 1, 2021, and the DHS-
69 form was completed on June 9, 2021.
In two out of four closed foster children’s records reviewed, the DHS-69 form was
not completed within three business days after the case was closed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval.
FOM 722-09
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
In four out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all of the USPs were not
reviewed and approved within 14 calendar days of the report date.
 For one record, one USP was completed on May 27, 2020, and it was
approved on June 12, 2020. One USP was completed on August 23, 2020,
and it was completed on September 10, 2020.
 For one record, one USP was completed on June 27, 2020, and it was
approved on July 23, 2020. One USP was completed on September 25,
2020, and it was approved on October 10, 2020. One USP was completed on
December 24, 2020, and it was approved on January 20, 2021. One USP
was completed on March 24, 2021, and it was approved on April 12, 2021.
 For one record, the USP was completed on March 11, 2021, and it was
approved in MiSACWIS on April 11, 2021.
 For one record, the USP was completed on July 26, 2020, and it was
approved in MiSACWIS on August 10, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of
the child's placement date. The actual date the foster care
12

provider receives the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
In seven out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the medical passport was
not provided to the child’s foster care provider per the timeframes specified in the
policy.
 For one record, the medical passport was not given to the relative caregiver
at or prior to the change of placement. The change of placement occurred on
March 1, 2021, and the relative caregiver signed the medical passport on
June 2, 2021.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed quarterly. It was signed
on May 18, 2020, October 21, 2020, January 16, 2021, and April 21, 2021.
 For one record, the child was placed in a foster home from April 30, 2020, to
August 6, 2020. The foster parent did not sign the medical passport quarterly.
It was signed on April 30, 2020. The child was placed in the relative
caregiver’s home on August 6, 2020. The relative caregiver did not sign the
medical passport quarterly. It was signed on August 6, 2020, December 18,
2020, April 2, 2021, and June 11, 2021.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed quarterly. It was signed
on August 4, 2020, January 15, 2021, and April 20, 2021.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed quarterly. It was signed
on February 25, 2020, June 15, 2020, December 11, 2020, March 11, 2021,
and June 8, 2021.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed within two weeks of the
placement and quarterly thereafter. The child was placed in the home on July
17, 2020. The medical passport was signed on September 4, 2020, October
1, 2020, January 5, 2021, and May 20, 2021.
 For one record, the medical passport was not signed quarterly. It was signed
on July 6, 2020, October 13, 2020, March 12, 2021, and June 15, 2021.
13

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
August 13, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED— 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
May 21, 2020.
DHHS Policy Health Requirements.
FOM 801-1
Dental examinations are required for children one year of age
and older, as follows:
 A dental examination within three months before entry
into foster care or an initial dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after entry
into a foster care out-of-home placement.
 A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every
six months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the dental examination was
not completed timely.
 For one record, the dental re-examinations were not completed every six
months. Dental re-examinations were completed on August 10, 2020, and
April 5, 2021.
 For one record, the dental re-examinations were not completed every six
months. Dental re-examinations were completed on October 14, 2020, and
June 5, 2021.
 For one record, the dental re-examinations were not completed every six
months. Dental re-examinations were completed on February 24, 2020,
August 3, 2020, and March 19, 2021.
DHHS Policy Personnel Training.
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors who
have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete security
awareness training (SAT). Training will be available on the
Learning Management System (LMS) for MDHHS personnel
and contractors with access to this system.
SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI
access completes the SAT. DCWL consultants will monitor
completion of SAT in all CPAs as part of the annual licensing
audit.
CI-182a was released to the field in December of 2016 advising
all current employees with access to CHRI to complete SAT
training no later than 02/10/2017. All other employees hired
14

after December of 2016 were required to complete SAT
according to the policy.
Six employees and one former employee were found to be in non-compliance to
timely certification of Security Awareness Training (SAT).
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
One CAP was in response to the 2020 Renewal Inspection findings.
The second was in response to Special Investigation 2021C0217009 where a
complaint was received stating the agency did not notify the court of the children’s
foster care worker changes and placement change; the agency failed to obtain a
court-ordered trauma assessment for the child; and the agency failed to file a
petition to terminate parental rights for the children. The agency was found in non-
compliance for R 400.12405 Change of Placement and R 400.12202 Policy and
procedures as the agency did not complete the DHS-69 forms timely after the foster
care worker changes and placement change; the agency did not complete a timely
trauma assessment referral for the child due to a new foster care worker being
assigned to the case and the foster care supervisor did not review the case in
monthly supervision or review the orders of the case as required; and the
termination of parental rights petition for the children was not completed timely. The
agency developed a corrective action plan that was appropriate and implemented as
verified with a random review of case files during this audit.
The staff and supervisors interviewed reported no concerns with the program. They
indicated that they have been working together as a team to manage the challenges
that the pandemic has caused such as staff turnover. They reported they are
committed to provide services to the children and families to assist in achieving
permanency for the children.
15

VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that the facility continue on a regular
license.
July 13, 2021
________________________________________
Alicia Wiggins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 13, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
16
